For me there are some areas where testing tools could do more.
 
The first=
 area is the integration in the IDE.  I would like to have
quickly an overv=
iew of the test of the selected object.
For example in eclipse, we can have=
 an overview of a class that we are
using.  We should have similar shortcut=
 to view the tests (maybe with
some descriptions?)

 
A second area concern=
s the creation of test values.  In some domain,
it is not unusual to have f=
unctions taking very 'long' value object as
input.  Some might argue that i=
t should be avoided, but it is not
always possible.  A good example where t=
hat can't be avoided is the
test of business rules in the insurance domain.=
  An insurance contract
contains really a lot of data, and the business rul=
es often use
totally unrelated part of the contract.
For such a case, I wou=
ld like to have a very simple editor to easily
edit the test value and stor=
e them into a file.  I think that some
adapted "bean editors" could do that=
, but I don't know if anybody has
already experiment this aproach.

 
Final=
ly, my last "dream" is probably much less clear than the two
previous point=
s, and certainly more complex.
I would like to see TDD colaborates with des=
ign by contract to give an
intermediate aproach taking the best of the two =
world.
I would like to be able to define somehow the contract of an
interfa=
ce, and I would like to have this contract validated when I run
the test, a=
nd that even when I stub or mock the object.  I'm convinced
that would allo=
w to write more powerful tests that would be less brillant.
And ho, I forgo=
t! My dream is to see that in java. :-)
